Software Engineer here, love the series. I have to disagree about comments.  Code should be clean and self-documenting. Comments should only be used when the code is not capable of expressing itself, or for APIs being distributed/used off-team. If you think you need a comment, then reevaluate and try refactoring the code.  The intention and behavior of code should be described by the tests, methods names, variable names, and class names  Domain knowledge should be taught to new team members upon joining via minor documentation outside the code.

Great overview but I do disagree on one point, commenting code. Your aim is to write code that is self documenting without the use of comments. The reason for this is that as code can change and it can be easy for a bit of code to be changed while the associated comments aren't. The one thing worst then no comments are wrong comments. There are places to put comments, like when describing an API or why your little bit of code looks like it could win a Rube Goldberg competition. But usually, making the code itself clean and concise is the best way to make it understandable. If you want to know more, I recommend Clean Code, The Pragmatic Programmer, or Code Complete 2 and great books to read.

Thank you :) I find it very difficult to decide wheter or not to use a new object. I get (or at least think I do) the "packaging" part - but I'm never sure if this is efficient. Do you have an easy answer for that too?

birawaich When creating 2 objects, the code, your functions, do not get duplicated. It is only the data fields that you get two copies of. So the object is represented in memory as the data fields put one after the other.

Thank you :) And if the data field is static, it all just links to the same memory address(es), right? So when making a final value one should always make it static as well, since the value won't be changed anyways. 1 question though: What's the difference between a static and a non-static function memory wise? (taking about java here)

@birawaich: In general, I stand by my original answer, that a new object creates a copy of the data fields, not a copy of the procedural code, but in your reply you delve into the finer details, which differ greatly from language to language. Also, within a single language, modifiers you talked about, do indeed produce different behavior.  The finer details are a long story, even though I will attempt to address your questions further down below. It is an art to put the general story in a 10 minute movie, which I feel Crash Course have done a pretty good job at. After you familiarize yourself with the basics, you can slowly develop a pretty good feel for how more specific situations work, just like your intuition about static variables was correct.

@birawaich: Now for your remarks and questions:  In your examples, making a variable static does indeed make all the objects reference the same memory location. You were correct about that.  You also suggested, that a final variable should also always be static, but that is not the case. A final, non-static variable is useful, in that each object does get its own copy of the variable, but it can only be initialized once in the constructor. So each object can indeed hold a different value for that variable, but it cannot be changed as long as the object lives. It is more of a data protection feature rather than a memory addressing feature.  Now the difference between static an non-static functions. Static functions operate on the static variables and cannot access the 'instance' variables. There is only one copy of the function, and it only accesses the one copy of the static variables. Non-static functions can access both static variables and instance variables. Static variables will be accessed directly at the single memory location, while instance members are accessed by first hopping to the memory location where the object resides and then go to the relative position where the variable resides. The memory location of the object is passed to the instance function as a hidden parameter, called the 'this' argument. You cannot see it in the higher level language, but under the hood, it's there!  Further details are left out of the story above, since the compiler of the higher level language, Java in your case, will not always work directly with that memory, but will strategically make temporary copies of those values in faster pieces or memory, making the question 'what does this variable look like memory-wise' a harder question to answer. But don't wreck your brain about it. After a procedure is done, in general the struct-like piece of memory is what represents the object.

Like almost all commonly used languages it is neither a pure functional nor pure object-oriented language, but simply multi-paradigm. However in practice it is far more OO than functional, the standard library is strongly built around class hierarchy, it's common to see use of classes  as the solution to any complex problems, functions often have side effects, and it's discouraged by Guido to use lambdas.

The basic properties of functional programming are immutability and composing programs out of expressions and function calls, not statements. Python has statements and mutability by default, so I think you can't seriously call it a functional language. And if you compare it with actual functional languages (like Haskell or the ML family), you will see it has much more in common with other OOP languages than with the functional languages.

svick Nope. The basic property is functions as the chief means of problem decomposition. Instead of, say, first-order logical propositions, a'la Prolog. Mutation is very much allowed, as in all lisps. Even your venerated Haskell has mutable state; just very well wrapped in a so-called monad.

+Ian Kjos, let's see what the first sentence of Wikipedia says on this: "In computer science, functional programming is a programming paradigm—a style of building the structure and elements of computer programs—that treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions and avoids changing-state and mutable data." You talk about Objects like they're required. Some of us actively avoid object oriented code.

One of my colleagues had the philosophy of never documenting code. When asked why, he said it was because programmers are so lazy that when they change the code, they do not change the comments, and inaccurate comments are worse than no comments at all. Also, he and his team handed over their product for porting to another language (Pascal to C) and we asked, "where are the comments?". He replied, "there are 300,000 lines of comments in this code."

You have to be careful when you're dealing with pure object-oriented programming, as you could easily end up in a situation where you need to re-use a subclass on its own or the excess abstraction ends up tying up the CPU in excess branching and/or cache misses. In other words, objects need to be defined in such a way that a computer need not interpret the object too much in order to use it. It's not that OO is a bad thing in and of itself, but one needs to understand that computers do not think this way.

I've been writing code for 15 years and that's no excuse to "never" comment. Programmers are not lazy, they are focused - they fix the code because that fixes the problem, if the comments don't get updated then they will get updated or removed in the next refactor. And if you know what you're doing, you're not commenting everywhere anyway. A programmer doesn't need a comment to know what the code does (only students rely on comments) a programmer looks at the code first anyway so see what it's doing, and he may glance at the comments to see what the previous programmer (often himself) was thinking. I tend to comment when I want to tell someone "why" I wrote this code, not what the code does. Rule of thumb, if there's a code-smell  add a comment to explain why you wrote it that way, otherwise if the methods/variables are named effectively and you're code isn't bloated, then no comment is really needed.

+seasong Documentation is highly dependent on your audience. The Linux kernel only needs documentation for people who want to make changes. Users of the Linux kernel generally do not care how the code works, just that it compiles and they can boot it. Conversely, consider the `git` source control tool. There the interface needs to be clearly documented because of the way users interact with it. It is also much more likely that a user of `git` will want to make a change to the core functionality.

It can't be emphasised enough (and Carrie Anne did at least mention it with 'revisit') how important good documentation, such as comments, is for the programmer is writing the code, let alone anyone else. The first priority should be making sure the code itself is clear. As in, things are named clearly, it's clearly formatted, things are done in a way that's obvious to readers. If the task at hand can't be done that way, then a comment explaining WHY the code is that way is good practice. There may be historical or institutional reasons some code had to be written a certain way that's won't be obvious in the code itself. Also, if you're writing a library, usage docs and examples are really helpful, as well as the intent of the library.  TLDR; comments should focus on WHY not how, and should not be a cover for poor coding practices, but illuminate things that one would not be able to ascertain from reading the code itself.

Version control software comes in many forms, and historically were mostly centralized in the way that darthjoey91 described, and does indeed sometimes involve "checking out" files. Only one user at a time is allowed to have a file "checked out", and after they check it back in, the next person who checks it out is expected to start by editing what the last user checked back in.  Such systems are getting rarer all the time because it makes concurrent work on the same file very difficult, and now Git, a distributed (rather than centralized) version control system, is the most popular. Unfortunately Git was originally developed solely to manage the Linux kernel, and many of its commands were not thought through with immense care about usability or sense to the general programmer population, so the old term "checkout" was grandfathered into it even though nothing is occurring which is analogous to checking a physical item out of a physical repository - whether "checkout" was chosen because of its similarity to a similar operation in more centralized systems, I can only speculate.  Source: I work on GitKraken, a git client that tries to make those commands less confusing.

Re: variable names. There's a balance to strike. For instance, using the letter "i" as a shorthand for "array index" is common practice, and there's no reason to write anything more explicit. I code in college, and I get a lot of stick for it.

Code should be self-documenting. Of course, if you're developing for other users, then your API should be well documented. Other than that comments should be rare, and only used when... well... Uncle Bob puts it best: "[we need] to compensate for our failure to express ourselves in code"

No human thinks in a programming language. The concept of "self-documenting code" is helpful, but also an extreme that can never be met. Code should be designed such that it's as easy to understand as possible, but comments are still highly important and recommended when working with other people, or even when coming back to your code 10 months later. Sure, you could read through the code and follow the functions back and forth and understand it, but you shouldn't have to spend that time when a well-placed comment could explain it easily for you.  The main reason comments are so important even with the best coding practices: functions are the programming equivalent of "see page 723, figure A, model IV, then come back and now go look at page 8762, paragraph 3, subsection Q".... we make fun of that kind of jumping around when lawyers do it, but code does it all the time. That's why it's best to comment your code rather than expecting humans to jump around like that.

What's the problem with verbose method names, etc? Is the code too wide for your screen? Wrap it. Is it too long? It probably should be refactored to smaller methods. Sure there are times and places for comments, but I don't often need to put them in the actual code.  Does internal code need, e.g. JavaDoc? Not really. Does a library? Of course its external API should have documentation! It's meant to be consumed by others.  Perhaps it's because I work on a small team, but I rarely find the need to comment something instead of refactoring code to be more readable.
function printText(text){  console.log(text); }  function printACountToN(n){  for(let i = 0; i < n; i++) printText(i); }

Let's be clear. There's a difference between uncommented, poorly written code, commented poorly written code, and uncommented well written self-documenting code. Fact of the matter is, comments often lie. People update the code without updating the comment, causing lots of lost time when someone assumes the code does what the comment says when the actual functionality has changed.
